In a world where everyone wears Zara and smells like it, too, why not stand out? It’s not advertised, but it’s pretty much an open secret that Zara scents are replicated off the world’s top designer fragrances. This is great if you’re on a budget, but sometimes, it’s worth it to get Zara perfume alternatives and smell like the real thing. That’s because houses like Tom Ford, Louis Vuitton, and Dior expertly source their high-quality notes and hire masterful perfumers to create blends that justify the price tag. These Zara alternatives are typically well-balanced, a trait Zara perfumes share, but they usually have more nuance depth, project better, and last a lot longer. So, if you find yourself itching for the real thing, whether it’s for a gift or to add to your collection, you’ve come to the right place. There are warm and cozy seasonal fragrances, fresh citrus blends for everyday wear, and even scents with unique notes that will leave you standing out from all the rest. Let’s have a look at the top 9 Zara perfume alternatives for men to consider. Key Takeaways  I began this assignment by poring over hundreds of photos, customer reviews, and the top scent blogs until I whittled down my list to the 10 finalists you see here. Overall, the best Zara perfume alternative for men is Tom Ford Gray Vetiver because it’s fresh, clean, easy to wear, and mass-appealing. For a fruity, complex alternative, look no further than the original Tiziana Terenzi Kirke. In This Article Our PicksBuying ConsiderationsHow We ChoseWhy Trust Us? Final VerdictFAQs davidsscents / Instagram Vetiver Pamplemousse vs. Tom Ford Gray Vetiver Why it’s great: There’s nothing wrong with wanting everyone to like you, and spritzing on Gray Vetiver is a step in the right direction. Salty notes and sunny, woody accords give it the same fresh and deep tones as Zara, making it easy to wear pretty much all year long. This Zara perfume alternative for men begins with a bright citrus note that fades into a woody vetiver base that is both refreshing and sophisticated. Though elegant and approachable, it’s a somewhat safe fragrance, a fresh and clean, refined type of scent that doesn’t reach out because it doesn’t really need to. Who is this for? For the guy who has his sleeves rolled up on his white collared shirt on a warm afternoon in the financial district. Flaws but not deal-breakers: This fragrance doesn’t evolve much, with a somewhat linear scent profile. Top Notes: Grapefruit, orange blossom, sage | Middle Notes: Nutmeg, orris root, pimento | Base Notes: Vetiver, woodsy notes, oakmoss, amber | Type: Eau de Parfum Vibrant Leather vs. Creed Aventus Why it’s great: Chances are, you’ve heard of the mesmerizing, best-selling Creed Aventus. Much like Vibrant Leather, it has a fruity top with notes of pineapple and a reliable woody base, balancing salty citrus and smoky accords with a masculine leather dry down to perfection. Though it’s a chypre fruity scent, this Zara perfume alternative for men is not overly sweet. An extremely well-balanced beast of a projector that retains its bouquet handsomely as time wears on. Who is this for? For the masculine guy who doesn’t mind smelling a little bit provocative and definitely unique. Flaws but not deal-breakers: The price is steep here, so many would consider this a splurge. Top Notes: Bergamot, black currant, apple, lemon, pink pepper | Middle Notes: Pineapple, patchouli, Moroccan jasmine | Base Notes: Birch, musk, oak moss, ambroxan, cedarwood | Type: Eau de Parfum Tobacco Collection Warm Rich Addictive vs. Tom Ford Tobacco Vanille Why it’s great: Warm yet spicy with a dash of the gourmand and a hint of vanilla, this is a beautiful scent for the cooler months of the year. The spicy tobacco opening smells incredibly realistic before growing sweet within a few minutes. A gorgeous vanilla dry down with slight woody piney notes gives it a dry, fresh, and slightly mysterious sillage. Definitely masculine and long-lasting. I love that it smells expensive. Who is this for? Spray on a warm winter’s night, enjoying red wine in a cozy, dimly-lit bar with good friends. I picture it on the mature guy who doesn’t mind something slightly overpowering. Flaws but not deal-breakers: Though it’s distinctive, some find this Zara perfume alternative for men to be somewhat polarizing. Top Notes: Tobacco leaf, spicy notes | Middle Notes: Vanilla, cacao, tonka bean, tobacco blossom | Base Notes: Dried fruits, woody notes | Type: Eau de Parfum Lisboa Colombo Avenida de Colegio Militar vs. Armani Acqua di Gio Why it’s great: It’s youthful but not young. It’s really hard not to love this one. Much like Lisboa, the famed Aqua di Gio is comprised of fresh floral citrus aquatics that lend it a delicate, fresh aroma reminiscent of jasmine. Perfect under the scorching Mediterranean sun, it combines sweet and salty notes with seawater and sunny warmth for a timeless projection that truly lasts forever. In this Zara perfume alternative for men, sharp spices are softened by a woody base with a warm, musky trail for a sexy, soft, and subtle sillage. It’s definitely popular, but not hard to see why: this summery scent is versatile and as easy to wear as a pair of swim trunks. Who is this for? Definitely for the fancy guy on a warm, luxurious vacation. Flaws but not deal-breakers: If you’re looking for something niche and/or unique, look elsewhere. Top Notes: Lime, lemon, bergamot, jasmine, orange, mandarin orange, neroli | Middle Notes: Sea notes, jasmine, calone, rosemary, peach, freesia, hyacinth, cyclamen, violet, coriander, rose, nutmeg, mignonette | Base Notes: White musk, cedar, oak moss, patchouli, amber | Type: Eau de Toilette Blue Spirit vs. Paco Rabanne Invictus Why it’s great: This is the ultimate blue scent that makes you feel fresh and sporty. Things open up with fresh grapefruit and marine accords that lead to a heart of aromatic bay leaf and jasmine before mellowing into a woody base. This Zara perfume alternative for men is fresh, sweet, and good for young people, especially because of the low price point. I like that it’s deliciously candy-like, with a decent mint bubble gum spin on your typical freshie. Suitable for all occasions, it’s an objectively good scent boasting excellent performance and compliment collection. Who is this for? Perfect for the guy who doesn’t want something adventurous but rather a fresh, classic scent that doesn’t require any forethought. Flaws but not deal-breakers: Though it’s what’s on the inside that counts, the cheesy bottle is disdained by scent snobs. Top Notes: Sea notes, grapefruit, mandarin orange | Middle Notes: Bay leaf, jasmine | Base Notes: Ambergris, guaiac wood, oakmoss, patchouli | Type: Eau de Toilette Tender Amber vs. Tiziana Terenzi Kirke Why it’s great: Like Tender Amber, this cologne is sweet and fruity but carries a luxurious, indulgent note. With a sweet green synthetic opening, things turn deliciously glamorous in the dry down as it fades into an exquisite musk. A beautiful, balanced blend of vibrant fruits and earthy patchouli. Even though it’s sweet, it’s lovely and complex. Definitely a grown-up fruity with a unique profile and bomb sillage. Both delicate and bold, it whispers yet leaves a lasting impression. Who is this for? Perfect for the guy who wants a sweet, fruity scent that can be described only as ‘unforgettable.’ Flaws but not deal-breakers: This is one of the best Zara perfume alternatives, but it may be too loud or sweet for the office. Best when worn in open spaces. Top Notes: Sand accord, blackcurrant buds, passionfruit, pear, peach, raspberry | Middle Notes: Lily of the valley | Base Notes: Patchouli, sandalwood, musk, heliotrope, vanilla | Type: Extrait de Parfum Zara for Him Red Edition vs. Maison Francis Kurkdjian Baccarat Rouge 540 Extrait de Parfum Why it’s great: Another pricey little number, Baccarat Rouge brings the luxurious complexity to justify the price point. Boasting an in-depth mix of sweet, metallic, and salty, with a slightly medicinal note, it’s genuinely considered a masterpiece of modern perfumery. Notes of sweet pineapple and saffron strike out at first spray, with a warm tobacco note coming out after a few hours before mellowing into a woody amber glow. I love that it’s warm on the skin yet unmistakably fresh, giving it a stylish appeal. This Zara perfume alternative for men will make anyone who wears it feel–and appear—attractive. Who is this for? For the guy who absolutely wants to smell stylish and original—during the cooler months, at least. Flaws but not deal-breakers: This one is very expensive and might not be worth the price tag for some. Top Notes: Saffron, jasmine | Middle Notes: Amberwood, ambergris, hedione | Base Notes: Fir resin, cedar, sugar, ambroxan, oakmoss | Type: Extrait de Parfum Night Pour Homme vs. Dior L’Homme Parfum Intense Why it’s great: This is a cologne you can’t put on without a dress shirt. It’s elegant and smooth, with a floral powdery note of iris that it shares with Night Pour Homme. It opens with a burst of lavender followed closely behind by cedar and a touch of vanilla. To get that woody note, make sure to spray it on your skin. Though many consider this a romantic winter evening fragrance, I find it to be light enough for all year round. A sweet, powdery scent that still feels masculine. Definitely high-class. Who is this for? This Zara perfume alternative for men is for the distinguished gent who wants to seal the deal in business or on his wedding day. Flaws but not deal-breakers: Some find it cloying or nauseating in hot weather. Top Notes: Lavender | Middle Notes: Iris, ambrette (musk mallow), pear | Base Notes: Virginia cedar, vetiver | Type: Eau de Parfum Sunrise on Red Sand Dunes vs. Louis Vuitton Imagination Why it’s great: Like floating inside a cloud on a sunny day, this fresh and inviting scent creates a positive mood. With a boost of sensuality and masculine elegance, it’s pretty easy to reach for, though it’s unique and nuanced thanks to unexpected tea notes. It opens with a fresh, clean orange peel aroma, followed by ginger and tea. It’s a simple citrus aromatic with soapy fresh notes, but you can tell it’s well-blended. I love that you can catch a whiff of yourself at random moments, garnering compliments as it shimmers on the skin all day long. Who is this for? Vetiver Pamplemousse vs. Tom Ford Gray Vetiver

Why it’s great: There’s nothing wrong with wanting everyone to like you, and spritzing on Gray Vetiver is a step in the right direction. Salty notes and sunny, woody accords give it the same fresh and deep tones as Zara, making it easy to wear pretty much all year long.

This Zara perfume alternative for men begins with a bright citrus note that fades into a woody vetiver base that is both refreshing and sophisticated. Though elegant and approachable, it’s a somewhat safe fragrance, a fresh and clean, refined type of scent that doesn’t reach out because it doesn’t really need to.

Who is this for? For the guy who has his sleeves rolled up on his white collared shirt on a warm afternoon in the financial district.

Tobacco Collection Warm Rich Addictive vs. Tom Ford Tobacco Vanille

Who is this for? Definitely for the fancy guy on a warm, luxurious vacation.
